title: Premier League team of the week as Adama Traore joins Liverpool and Arsenal pair
text:

Liverpool head into the international break with a vice-like grip on the Premier League, and pundits declaring that this season's title is very much theirs to lose.

The Reds' 2-1 win over Leicester City, coupled with Manchester City's 2-0 defeat at home to Wolves, means Jurgen Klopp's men have opened up an eight-point gap at the top of the table.

James Milner scored the winner at Anfield on Saturday from the penalty spot, after Sadio Mane's opener had been cancelled out by James Maddison.

And on Sunday it was Adama Traore who was the toast of Merseyside, scoring a double at the Etihad.

(Image: Getty Images)

Elsewhere, Arsenal moved upto third with a 1-0 win over Bournemouth, courtesy of David Luiz, while Chelsea, with 18 goals scored and 14 conceded, are not fifth, after scoring four at Southampton.

Crystal Palace and Burnley both claimed wins, as did Aston Villa, romping to a five-goal thrashing of Norwich at Carrow Road.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's United completed a miserable weekend for the city of Manchester however, losing 1-0 at Newcastle United; it was Steve Bruce's 23rd game against the Red Devils as a manager, and he had never previously tasted victory.

Anyway, ignoring all that, here's the Mirror Football team of the week, where we've gone back to basics with a pretty straightforward 4-4-2...

Mat Ryan (Brighton)

The Australia No.1 must have been expecting a more difficult afternoon on the south coast.

But on a weekend when no goalkeeper was particularly outstanding, Ryan gets the nod because, everything he needed to do, he did well.

Called upon late on he made a couple of smart saves - notably from Lucas Moura - while he also used his feet well throughout to give the Seagulls an out ball, allowing them to build again.

Calum Chambers (Arsenal)

After a couple of seasons out on loan and out of favour, the 24 year-old is now back en vogue at the Emirates and is impressing.

With Unai Emery easing Hector Bellerin back into action after his long stint on the sidelines, Chambers started at right-back against Bournemouth and did a fine job against Josh King.

He defended his back post stoutly, no one made more successful tackles than his four, and also got forward to support the attack whenever opportunity knocked.

(Image: NEIL HALL/EPA-EFE/REX)

Willy Boly (Wolves)

When the 28 year-old is fully focused, there are very few defenders better in the entire Premier League, and he showed precisely why in Wolves ’ win over Manchester City .

Wanderers’ 6ft4in man mountain was outstanding throughout on Sunday, winning more aerial challenges (5) and making more clearances (12) than anyone else.

He also made a couple of crucial interceptions as he kept Sergio Aguero and Pep Guardiola’s champions quiet.

Lewis Dunk (Brighton)

The Brighton captain can’t get a look in with England right now, but his display against Tottenham will have given Three Lions boss Gareth Southgate plenty to think about in that regard.

The Seagulls switched from a back three to a back four, and Dunk was outstanding at the heart of defence, stopping attacks, dealing (physically) with Harry Kane and playing out from the back.

Spurs’ much documented struggles - particularly pressing high - meant Dunk ended the day with a pass completion of 89 percent, including one wonderful assist for Connolly’s second.

(Image: 2019 Getty Images)

Jetro Willems (Newcastle)

The Dutch international missed the thumping at Leicester having started the previous three matches, but back in against Manchester United , Willems impressed.

He locked up his flank, dealing pretty comfortably with both Dan James and Andreas Pereira, and also played his part in the winner, teeing up Matty Longstaff.

Interestingly, only Allan Saint-Maximin completed more dribbles than him on the field, while he also made three key passes. A smart performance at both ends.

Adama Traore (Wolves)

The former Barcelona junior had scored just once in the Premier League for Wolves before the final 10 minutes at the Etihad on Sunday.

Then, having spent much of the game shackling Raheem Sterling while operating as a wing-back, the flying Spaniard burst through the heart of Manchester City’s defence on two occasions, and coolly finished past Ederson both times.

Nuno Espirito Santo has worked hard with the rapid winger in recent months, and he’s repaid him by arguably being the side’s best player so far this term.

(Image: REUTERS)

Conor Hourihane (Aston Villa)

Aston Villa arrived at Carrow Road with a game plan, to press Norwich players repeatedly, getting in their faces and then picking off mistakes.

No-one did that better than Conor Hourihane, brought back into the Villa side at the heart of midfield.

The 28 year-old ran amok in Norfolk, assisting Wesley’s second, winning a penalty and then scoring with an excellent strike himself.

James Milner (Liverpool)

A typically industrious display from the ex-England international, who proved decisive in the key moments as Liverpool moved eight points clear at the top of the table.

It was Milner’s penalty that ultimately handed the Reds victory in the 95th minute, but his role in Sadio Mane’s opener shouldn’t be underestimate, a fine, arcing pass - with his weaker foot - catching out Jonny Evans.

“Exceptional,” declared Jurgen Klopp post-game. He certainly was.

(Image: Getty Images)

Jack Grealish (Aston Villa)

Pushed from a central midfield role into the front three for Villa this weekend, captain Grealish was outstanding in the Villans’ 5-1 thumping of Norwich City.

Typically he was at the heart of everything good about Dean Smith’s side, scoring, creating chances, and having more touches and making more passes in the opposing half than any other Villa player (50 and 34).

His goal was a fine finish, but was only his first in the Premier League this term. His next task is adding more to his game.

Aaron Connolly (Brighton)

As far as first Premier League starts go, Aaron Connolly’s takes some beating.

The 19 year-old Irish forward was here, there and everywhere against Spurs, with a whizzing display where he seemingly covered every blade of grass.

Spurs defence couldn’t get a handle on his speed and movement, while he also linked smartly with Neale Maupay. His goals were the icing on the cake.

(Image: 2019 Getty Images)

Tammy Abraham (Chelsea)

"He’s not just a handful for defenders,” says Frank Lampard. “He has good feet, holds up the ball well. He is also getting goals which is brilliant for him.”

And again, the England forward, back in the Three Lions squad this month, was on target at St Mary’s.

Abraham is the leading goalscorer in the Premier League right now - level with Sergio Aguero - and Southampton ’s defenders will be having nightmares following his showing.

The Chelsea striker is really coming of age this term.
description: Liverpool moved eight points clear heading into the international break, as Manchester City and Manchester United both lost
